body: What's the use case for knowing the HTTP version? I'll look into making the `remote_addr` available.

Well, I agree that HTTP version may not appear immediately useful. However, in general hiding this kind of information gives you little, while exposing as much as possible will definitely give your users things to experiment with.

I believe in keeping the API as clean and simple as possible. If there's something that's unused 99% of the time with little reason to use it the rest, I don't believe that feature should be included. That may or may not be the case with exposing the HTTP version - I've personally never had a need for it. Still, I'll tag this "feedback wanted"; perhaps someone else has a good reason to have it exposed.

Remote address is *definitely* useful. *Many* types of apps want to record the remote IP address for audit logs.

Itâ€™s also quite plausible that you might want to implement things differently in HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2.0, e.g. bundle things up for HTTP/1.1 or use server push of more smaller resources in HTTP/2.0.

I have no qualms about exposing the remote address. I'm looking for use cases on exposing the HTTP version. I'm not sure returning different responses depending on the HTTP version is something I want Rocket to encourage or allow.
Since no one has chimed in about a reason to expose the HTTP version, it will not be exposed.

issue.title: Expose HTTP Version, Server Name, Server Port, URL Scheme on Request
issue.body:
Thank you for this library. I find it a joy to use, which is why I am trying to leverage it in [ferrocarril](https://github.com/lopopolo/ferrocarril).

## Feature Requests

I am building a [Rack](https://github.com/rack/rack)-compatible Ruby web application server with Rocket similar to [Thin](https://github.com/macournoyer/thin). Rack is a set of HTTP building blocks. It defines an [environment](https://www.rubydoc.info/github/rack/rack/file/SPEC#label-The+Environment) which is a `Hash` containing information about the incoming HTTP request (see https://github.com/lopopolo/ferrocarril/issues/61).

One item in the Hash is the HTTP version. I found GH-38 which discusses exposing the HTTP Version from Hyper, but decided not to do so because there wasn't a compelling reason to expand the API surface area. I hope this is the compelling reason :wink:.

Rocket provides high-level HTTP building blocks that I would like to use instead of dropping down to Hyper, but building frameworks with Rocket in this case requires knowing the internal details of the HTTP request.

The other data I need to fill out the Rack environment that I'm unclear how to access includes:

- server name
- server port
- url scheme (http vs https)

This feature needs to exist inside of Rocket because Rocket is hiding this information from the underlying Hyper request.

The right answer here might be that I need to use Hyper directly, and if that is the case I'm happy to do so. Thanks again! ðŸ˜„
